stem: Complete the following clinical statement regarding brain tumor postoperative positioning.
template: Following a supratentorial craniotomy, the nurse should position the patient with the head of the bed elevated to 30-45 degrees to promote {{blank1}} and prevent increased {{blank2}}.

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed after a supratentorial craniotomy facilitates venous outflow from the brain, reducing cerebral blood volume and intracranial pressure (ICP). This positioning helps prevent cerebral edema and hematoma formation, promoting optimal neurological recovery.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect options reflect misunderstandings of the physiological effects of positioning after supratentorial craniotomy. Arterial inflow is not the primary concern; head elevation primarily affects venous drainage. CSF leakage is not the primary goal of this positioning. While positioning can influence blood pressure and cerebral perfusion, the primary concern post-craniotomy is managing ICP.

clinicalPearls: Monitor neurological status frequently after craniotomy to detect early signs of increased ICP.
Maintain strict aseptic technique when managing surgical dressings to prevent infection.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the effects of positioning on arterial versus venous blood flow.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that elevation primarily aids venous drainage, reducing ICP.

reviewUnits.heading: Key Concept Review
reviewUnits.body: Postoperative positioning following a supratentorial craniotomy is critical for managing intracranial pressure and promoting optimal neurological recovery. Elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees facilitates venous drainage, reducing cerebral blood volume and subsequently lowering ICP. Regular neurological assessments and proper wound care are essential components of postoperative care.
